labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Comment on "Priority within a Flow (Intra-Flow)"
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
Without a signaling in place between a receiving host and its network, remote peers are able to mark every packet of a flow as important, causing much the same problem as the previous use-case. Eventually, when all packets of every flow are marked as important, there is no differentiation between packets within a flow, rendering the network unable to improve reactive policy decisions.

Comment> The above text is not clear to me. How will the signaling mechanism between a receiving host and its network prevent a misbehaving remote peer from marking every packet of a flow as import ? 

The signalling requirement to detect and block such a misuse is not discussed in this section.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
Worse, the text in the I-D is discussing *inter* flow priority.  That is, priority between flows, where every flow says "I am important".  But we have agreed to constrain the I-D to discuss only priority of packets within a single flow (that is, within a 5-tuple).  So, *intra* flow priority.

The value of signaling from client to the ISP's router is in getting agreement to honor the intra-flow priority values, and getting agreement how they are signaled from server-to-client -- can they be signaled with UDP Options?  Can they be signaled with DSCP?  Can they be signaled with QUIC Connection IDs?  Can they be signaled with RTP/SRTP SSRC?  The ISP router knows what it supports, the client (from discussions with the server) knows what the server supports.  They can find a mutually-agreed-upon signaling mechanism.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
Yes, I updated the metadata scope section in the pull request to clarify that inter flow priority is out of scope by adding the following text: 

The metadata can be used by the network to prioritize traffic within a single 5-tuple connection and metadata cannot be leveraged for prioritization between different flows.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Worse, the text in the I-D is discussing _inter_ flow priority. That is, priority between flows, where every flow says "I am important".

We need to put in bold that the focus is intra-flow or flows of the same user. I updated the abstract to have the warning early in the document. Otherwise, we will be opening lot of noise.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > Worse, the text in the I-D is discussing _inter_ flow priority. That is, priority between flows, where every flow says "I am important".
> 
> We need to put in bold that the focus is intra-flow or flows of the same user. I updated the abstract to have the warning early in the document. Otherwise, we will be opening lot of noise.

Prioritizing flows from the same host is also error-prone because the network cannot distinguish between legitimate and malicious flows. For example, a poorly written application might request the highest priority for its flows, which could be unjustified. Additionally, it is challenging to identify whether the traffic belongs to a single user or multiple users, such as in tethering scenarios. Therefore, I propose focusing solely on "intra-flow" prioritization. Both WebRTC and QUIC, multiplex multiple streams on the same 5-tuple.

issues.title: Comment on "Priority between Flows"
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body: I don't agree with the text in this section. The scope of this draft is to discuss the use cases and requirements for prioritizing of packets within a flow and not between flows. Prioritizing between flows is error-prone because the host can have both malicious and legitimate applications, and the remote peers can also be malicious and benign.

issues.title: Relative Priority of Media Frames
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body: The sections 5.1.2 and 5.1.4 are repeating the text, remove one of these sections.

issues.title: Burst Indication
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
The server may also signal end of burst that provides information for the radio to go into sleep mode (Connected Mode Discontinuous Reception, C-DRX) if there is no paging message.

Comment> The requirement seems specific to 3GPP, can you add a reference to the document ?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: Supposedly 3gpp got the idea from 802.11ba, according to https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/9686039.  So should cite both 3gpp spec as well as 802.11ba, https://standards.ieee.org/ieee/802.11ba/6896/

issues.title: Abuse and Constraints
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
## Abuse and Constraints {#abuse}

It is important that not every flow be prioritized; otherwise, the network devolves into the best-effort network that existed prior to metadata signaling. It is a requirement that mechanisms exist to prevent this occurrence.

Such a mechanism might be simple, for example, a cellular network might allow one flow from a subscriber to declare itself as important; other flows with that subscriber are denied attempts to prioritize themselves.

Comment> The network cannot identify whether the prioritized flow is legitimate or malicious. It has no info to detect malicious flows, if several flows mark themselves as important. I don't think prioritizing a flow over others is in the scope of this draft.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: The text quoted from the I-D ("It is important that not every flow be prioritized") is referring to *inter* flow priority, which is out of scope for the I-D.  Remove.

issues.title: Highlight the requirements
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body: It will be helpful to highlight the requirements associated with each use case, for instance, see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc7478/

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body:
In use cases, will it make sense to follow the below format to make it clear?

Use case:
Problem: 
Solution How signaling helps/solves:

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> In use cases, will it make sense to follow the below format to make it clear?
> 
> Use case: Problem: Solution How signaling helps/solves:

Use cases and requirements format should suffice, see RFC7478.

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body:
I took a shot at coming up with requirements for Media traffic type (Interactive and Streaming) to state the intent, requirement and the use case to focus on the need more than the way to solve it. Kind of kept the language generic without specifying whether it is a client to network or server to network so that this is applicable in P2P cases too. Please share your comments on the format. I put together the content from both signaling and hdr-wireless doc. Once we get the format fixed, I can expand it to other sections as well.

[RequirementsFormat.md](https://github.com/SpencerDawkins/net-collab-rqmts/files/15349795/RequirementsFormat.md)

issues.title: Intro updates on justification, diagram, etc
issues.author: John-Kaippallimalil
issues.body:
- Add justification for network's need for additional metadata.
- Per-flow and per-stream aspects, but remove inter-flow (align with updates in related issue)
- Handling priority per flow within a single user (i.e., a single user may have a connectivity session that is policed (e.g., not to exceed X Mbps). Within the connectivity session, there may be multiple flows, one of which may be a high bandwidth consumer and target for traffic shaping. In this context, the user may have a preference on which flow to prioritize or get information on how the flow is being shaped (e.g., bandwidth limit).
- Add new figure for the above.
- Update Figure 1: host -> client, host -> server (and throughout the section)

comments.author: John-Kaippallimalil
comments.body: Updates completed as noted above.

issues.title: Chapter 5 On path metadata requirements
issues.author: John-Kaippallimalil
issues.body:
In chapter 5:
- what is necessary for the client (as a stakeholder) to communicate to the network, server in relation to metadata exchange
- in the above, address the point that an opaque channel without client's acceptance will raise privacy 
- privacy considerations for extensible metadata? 

In chapter 5.1 and 5.2
- merge into one set of requirements that consider rationale, and what is needed  (i.e., why importance, delay tolerance, burst size/end)
- state that the above requirements may apply to multiple streams in a transport flow, or to frames of a media stream within a flow (but not both)

Align with any updates in related issue.

issues.title: API
issues.author: danwing
issues.body:
Along the lines of [SCONE's API](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-eddy-sconepro-api/), do we want to say anything about the API needs?

I noticed their API document conflates a single API with "receiving data over the QUIC flow", which of course isn't necessary considering that [ICMP errors are sent to (connected) UDP sockets](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/behave/ZXQ4xLYrqPB3CxLMnRNmzApK0oU/), and those are different flows. So, there could be a single API which does all your QUIC things and, under the covers, does a separate signaling channel with the ISP(s) router(s), exposing the information to the application without the application needing to do heavy lifting. We might call that a 'library' or I suppose in 2024 we would have to call that a 'framework' or 'wrapper' or some-such.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
This can be mentioned as part of a new OPS section, e.g., "Exposure Handling".

The local exposure (OS API) can be mentioned, e.g., next to REQ-SIGNAL-EXPOSURE-FAIRNESS in #25.

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: I thought this would be more of a metadata specific aspect but we could list the "framework" as a requirement in the signaling. In that case, do we need to have API(s) for the client/host to network signaling as well? Include that in the framework as well?

issues.title: Video requirements and encryption/decryption of metadata
issues.author: sridharangirish91
issues.body: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-joras-sconepro-video-opt-requirements-00 - In this draft, they seem to talk about key exchange that we have kept out (implementation part)... But wonder if we have already incorporated the rest in our draft under "media" itself. Should we dig a little deeper into the cryptographic stuff or at least come up with a different draft for that?

issues.title: Network to host section required?
issues.author: sridharangirish91
issues.body: In https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-joras-sconepro-video-opt-requirements-00, the requirements seem to have a network to host part, which we haven't focused much on here (some of it is in https://github.com/boucadair/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/blob/main/draft-brw-sconepro-rate-policy-discovery.md). Do we need to add a section iterating the requirements for network to host signaling to have a more holistic picture?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: Network should be able to tell host that previously-signaled conditions have changed (e.g., throughput has declined or increased).  Is more needed?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
The section titled "Network-Host Metadata" (currently Section 5.2) only mentions Assisted Offload.  It doesn't mention available bandwidth.  That's a major miss!  The abstract even mentions bandwidth!!  Oops.

I'll add text if Sridharan is already asleep.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Yes, agree. We need to have some text about this.

Know it is related to an associated REQ-FRAME-FIRST or -FRAME-LAST, and either send all of them or none of them.

If there is a better way to express this in requirements, go for it!

issues.title: Prioritizing flows from the same host
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body: Prioritizing flows from the same host is also error-prone because the network cannot distinguish between legitimate and malicious flows. For example, a poorly written application might request the highest priority for its flows, which could be unjustified. Additionally, it is challenging to identify whether the traffic belongs to a single user or multiple users, such as in tethering scenarios. Therefore, I propose focusing solely on "intra-flow" prioritization. Both WebRTC and QUIC, multiplex multiple streams on the same 5-tuple.

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: Should we maybe add text to the inter flow section saying "Due to these challenges, inter flow is out of scope of this document."?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @tireddy2, please see the discussion in https://github.com/SpencerDawkins/net-collab-rqmts/pull/33 for the reasoning to include this in the first version.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> @tireddy2, please see the discussion in #33 for the reasoning to include this in the first version.

Yes, I saw the discussion but I am not convinced how the network can distinguish between legitimate and malicious flows for prioritization ?
Further,  it is challenging to identify whether the traffic belongs to a single user or multiple users, such as in tethering scenarios.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
There might be methods to do that (more or less complex) but still this is possible. For example, legitimate flows can supply a token that is provided only to entitled ones. Also, the pref here is more about discard pref than taking higher prio.

tethering is still seen as a same subscriber/user. 

There are challenges that we need to record, for sure. However, let's  discuss this in the WG and see if the WG want to cover this or not. We need that discussion to happen publicly. Thanks.

comments.body:
> There might be methods to do that (more or less complex) but still this is possible. For example, legitimate flows can supply a token that is provided only to entitled ones. 

Who will provide the token to the applications and how will the network validate the token (in a scenario where is no agreement between the ISP and content provider) ?

> Also, the pref here is more about discard pref than taking higher prio.

Yes.

> 
> tethering is still seen as a same subscriber/user.

Okay.

>

Works for me but we may want to high-light the challenges in the draft for the WG to understand the complexities if this is to be supported.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> > Also, the pref here is more about discard pref than taking higher prio.
> 
> Yes.
> 
> > tethering is still seen as a same subscriber/user.
> 
> Okay.

Fully agree. Please update the text to list the challenges not already in the text.

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: This discussion can drift into implementation suggestions very quickly like suggesting token exchange etc, the reason why we kept client signalling of encryption key out of the draft as well. Listing the challenges and keeping it open ended is a good way, I agree.

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body:
Reading Med's comment again on this being applicable only to lowering the priority of flows, will any app do that in practice? I mean, what would an app vendor get from saying "Hey I have a lower priority". Assuming it is a perfectly fair world, apps can signal this when they are not being used but I wasn't sure if they'd ever signal this themselves. Letting the platform/OS do the bidding for them is a dangerous thing...

I was also wondering, will any OS companies like MSFT or Apple get into a deal with the big content giants like netflix and signal lowering flow priority for other apps themselves without anyone else noticing? Google could do the same with android to promote YouTube performance too... Will this be a concern? Especially if this signal is encrypted and the platform companies have tie ups with ISPs as well as a protocol between them to decrypt the signal, the platform companies could silently kill performance of other small-scale apps... Just wondering if this is a possibility or if I am flying into the crazy world, if we even choose to propose enabling control of inter-flow mechanism.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Reading Med's comment again on this being applicable only to lowering the priority of flows, will any app do that in practice?

It isn't intuitive to do so. However, with all the marketing hype and "commitments" for fair use of resources, some forms of this case may not be unrealistic.

issues.title: Add e2e model for metadata transfer, revise s2n requirements in 5.2, and miscellaneous (incl. gaps that requirements address)
issues.author: John-Kaippallimalil
issues.body:
a) E2E model of how the server-2-network and host-2-network metadata exchange takes place and the dependencies are not explicit. 
This includes the behavior expected in the network (i.e., shaping). Revise in section 1 (Introduction) to address.
b) Server-2-network requirement simplification: uplevel the requirements to state what the network shaper should act on (i.e., priority and tolerance to delay). Remove bursts, periodicity as behavior can be different across different access networks like WiFi and 5G. 
c) Add an Appendix section to identify what the state-of-the-art is for h2n and s2n is and what is missing. Focus on per-packet prioritization (in intro section also), and state why per-flow mechanisms like DSCP and reactive mechanisms like congestion control, ECN/L4S at a flow level are not sufficient.
d) Move "Network Attachment" details to an Appendix section as this is not a primary aspect of this draft.

issues.title: Consolidate and merge use cases, revise h2n sections
issues.author: John-Kaippallimalil
issues.body:
The following aspects are considered here:
a) use cases in section 3 need to be consolidated (to address the tsvwg comments)
    Media streaming (3.1) and Interactive media (3.2) can be combined. 
    Accommodate-Delay Traffic (3.3) and User Preferences (3.4) combined --> this can represent a traffic management option for flow control (i.e., the user prefers to prioritize flow 1 (UDP 4-tuple) over flow 2 belonging to the user.
    Remove 3.5 and 3.6 
b) Add the "flow control" description above to the Traffic Shaping/management in section 1.
c) Revise h2n section 5.1 to match the revision for flow preference (in b) and/or s2n metadata.
d) clarify "intra-flow". With the revisions in s2n (5.2), only priority of packet is visible and intra-flow (audio, video, etc) is not.
    On the other hand, a user may have multiple flows that are shaped and have preferences on that (see b above)

comments.author: John-Kaippallimalil
comments.body:
Revised the following:
a) consolidated use cases as noted above, and renamed requirements to REQ-FLOW-PRIORITY and REQ-FLOW-DELAY (flow being a UDP 4-tuple of a network attachment.
b) added aspects of network shaping/flow handling/network attachment in section 1
c) basic revision of h2n. 
d) intra-flow was removed as the network shaper has no visibility into a UDP 4-tuple flow that is encrypted.

issues.title: Client-Network metadata updates and Use case/requirements consolidation
issues.author: John-Kaippallimalil
issues.body:
1. Revise use case 4.3 to "Client Negotiating Metadata Support"

2. Client-network metadata updates:
a) remove section “Priority between flows” (5.1.1). 
b) Add new section on how the network is made aware of the transport by which metadata is sent (new 5.1.1 ?)
    Move 6.2 “Exposure Handling” to this section.  Would the title “Transport for Metadata Exposure” be clearer for the reader'

3. a) Rename section "Operational Considerations" -> "System Considerations"
    b) Move 6.1 to Appendix (as it is related to SconePro)

comments.author: John-Kaippallimalil
comments.body: issues in #76 are addressed.

issues.title: introduction is really long
issues.author: danwing
issues.body: Introduction would benefit from a diet, or at least breaking into sub-sections.  Some documents have a separate background section but existing text does not seem to talk a lot about existing systems.  Hm.  Suggestions?

comments.author: John-Kaippallimalil
comments.body:
I agree that section 1 (Intro) would benefit from breaking into 2 sections.
How about a short Introduction (section 1) that provides an overview of what's in the document, and 
A new section that follows ( -- something like "Rationale for Per-packet Metadata") which would contain the gist of what is currently in the intro but reduced in length (as much as possible).
Highlighting "per-packet metadata" in a section heading may also help bringing attention to "per-packet (vs. per-flow).

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: See how #91 feels -- I moved one new paragraph up, and slammed all the rest of the existing introduction into a new section 1.1, _Rational for Per-Packet Metadata_.

issues.title: Privacy Considerations would benefit from re-write
issues.author: danwing
issues.body:
Privacy Considerations is long and worries about some of the wrong things, like modifying the metadata by an on-path attacker.  This section should have a structure of:

1. traffic analysis is a problem for user privacy (e.g., ISP builds profile of streamed movies)
2. existing TLS, SRTP, and QUIC traffic is vulnerable to traffic analysis, and have some mitigations like padding
3. per-packet metadata makes traffic analysis easier
4. mitigations for (3) are:  encrypting/obfuscating per-packet metdata, mis-marking metadata
5. however, encrypting/obfuscating per-packet metadata is ineffective if threat is from the same network entity with the keys

pulls.title: add initial set of REQ- requirements
pulls.author: danwing

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Dan, please rebase to resolve conflicts. It is safe if you can do that check yourself. Thanks.

reviews.author: tireddy2
reviews.body: Yes, I like the proposed format for requirements.

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body: some quick comments

comments.body:
```suggestion
REQ-INTERACTIVE: The importance within interactive traffic flow depends on the type of application and the user activity. Requirements for different interactive media are listed below:
```

```suggestion
separately and, thus, can be signaled separately (requirement:
```
I would reword this as this is not inclusive. Video or signals are important for persons with inabilities. Refer to Total Conversation concept.

```suggestion
Audio is more critical than video for many applications, but its
```
Does this assume the host is always directly connected to the ISP network?

```suggestion
They may include digital models of the real world, multimedia content, virtualized desktop/apps, and interactive engagement.
```

```suggestion
Examples: VoIP (Peer-to-Peer (P2P), group conferencing), gaming, eXtended Reality (XR), Virtual Apps and Desktops.
```

No need to mention a product name :-)
No, it assumes the client can tell the ISP router the priority of the incoming flow as the client wants.  The client could be behind a NAT.

new wording is 'many applications', and many (most) people can hear.  We are well above 80/20 threshold of the common case that audio is more critical than video, most of the time.  The ability of the receiver to change the priority by communicating to the ISP -- without cooperation of the sender -- is a requirement and gives a hearing-impaired user the ability to adjust video above audio.
Agreed, especially the last part of your reply.
I would zoom into that part to avoid confusion.  We can reason about "upstream router (home router, ISP router, etc.)" to cover both direct and indirect cases

It'll be appealing to both small scale companies (and ones who operate behind data centers like Citrix) as well as net neutrality cause :)

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Agree with Dan. Updated the PR [df33111](https://github.com/SpencerDawkins/net-collab-rqmts/pull/12/commits/df33111fda853f00cf8412f26ce0a1e980685186)

pulls.title: Update draft-kwbdgrr-tsvwg-net-collab-rqmts.md
pulls.author: John-Kaippallimalil
pulls.body: Updates in Introduction section to address Issue: "Intro updates on justification, diagram, etc" #10

comments.body:
```suggestion
A connection session maybe established using control plane signaling between the client and the network (access) router and is out of scope of this document.
```
Are we limiting the scope of the document to media or including other types of traffic as well to extend the requirements for explicit signaling?

Interactive media is already described in the draft (req in section 5.1)
The others include: (a) a limited bandwidth due to large number of users, and a need to prioritize one flow over another (section 5.2 ?), (b) information from the network on, e.g., max bandwidth to allow better rate control.
If we document (b) then we should also refer to sconepro so that it is clear.
The model described in lines 150 - 152 is independent of these requirements pers se.
Do you think we need additional text about all this in the intro section?
seems "link capacity" is not consistent with "millisecond" mention.
can we have a reference to cite here?

Since the scheduling interval for 5G mid band is 0.5ms, there can be variations in that interval.
With mmWave, the scheduling interval is 0.0125 ms and much larger variations in capacity over that period of time.
Both number of users and change the wireless medium result in large link variations in sub-ms timeframes.
The argument was intended to say that rate estimation in CCA take multiple RTTs and that is several orders of magnitude slower than the change of radio link capacity.

If the above reasoning is ok, I'll re-write that sentence to be more clear :
"Wireless link capacity can vary in sub-millisecond timeframes while rate estimation at the server (sender) takes multiple RTTs, or several tens of milliseconds."

Probably many references, but two that are good:
1. 5G: Lumos5G: Mapping and Predicting Commercial mmWave 5G Throughput, Arvind Narayanan et al., ACM https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3419394.3423629
2. LTE: Stochastic Forecasts Achieve High Throughput and Low Delay over Cellular Links, Winstein et al., USENIX NSDI, https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/nsdi13/nsdi13-final113.pdf

In the draft, we could add (1) which is more recent.

Just to clarify the scheduling interval (0,5 ms, or 0.0125 ms) is the minimum period. The scheduler may allocate 10 or more slots to a user (less if there are more users). So the variation in capacity available for a user can be seen at 0.0125*10 onwards ~ 0.1ms for mmWave (and around 2-3 ms in congested 5G mid-band)

Maybe better wording would be:
"Wireless link capacity can vary in the order of a millisecond or less while CCA estimates of rate at the server (sender) takes multiple RTTs, or several tens of milliseconds".

I was zooming out a bit more to ask if we should include bulk transfer traffic as well to the mix (like backup/restore, downloads/uploads, print jobs etc) so that the document is more generic and not just confined to media traffic. That way, we got more requirements and use-cases as well to bolster the claim that explicit signaling is required to make things more efficient. There are cases where bulk traffic is also in the same application as interactive traffic (like saving a PPT or printing word file while continuing to type within a remote session (or cloud)). Will that be useful to include these as well in the draft?

Agreed would be useful to add.  To keep applicable to the web browser crowd, let's include 'downloading a file' as an example of a lower-priority thing.  With QUIC, that could occur with the same web server as other browsing but is obviously less important than the interactive stuff the user is doing with the same web server.

Agree, the use case would be good to document.
And the abstraction in figure with 2 flows (x1/x2)  in a connection session illustrate what the router sees.
Perhaps we should also think if additional requirements for metadata are needed. (my earlier response assumes that the h2n network requirements capture this.)

John, are we trying to handle two flows owned by the same application?  Like, I am visiting www.example.com and click on a file to download from files.example.com (a different server)??  

Perhaps we can allow inter-flow priority if a flow is declaring itself as *lower* priority, but not *higher* priority??

I worry that we don't now, or won't in the future, have such a binary "lower priority", though...

In the figure, it is 2 flows owned by different servers (srv-1, srv-2) as in the "example.com" example with file download from another server.  The figure was trying to illustrate the GBR/non-GBR (best effort) sessions in 5G, and be general enough to cover the different cases. 

In a way, inter-flow priority of sorts is there in the network, but not signaled.
For example, the problem in Sconepro is that one flow (YouTube) out of many of a non-GBR/ BE session(i.e., has the same signaled connection info between UE - 5G network) is a heavy consumer of bandwidth while other flows in the conn session are not. The flows are all to different servers. The traffic shaper in 5G (UPF) only reduces rate for the high bw user (Youtube) and leaves the others unchanged. My understanding is that Sconepro wants to provide a direct signal as to how the network is constraining that high bw user, i.e., max flow bw.

comments.body: Should we mention that this is out of the scope of the document, and we only discuss intra-flow? If we are not focusing on inter-flow, do we need a separate section for it? I was thinking of mentioning what inter-flow is and that is out of the scope in a single in as part of intra-flow and remove the whole section here so that it avoids any confusion at all (c.f https://github.com/SpencerDawkins/net-collab-rqmts/pull/27/files).

I do see a value in keeping the text in the first version of the draft but with reasonable caveats such as be restricted to flows bound to the same user/host.

We can limit the scope to cases where an app can lower its preferences and the like.

same user/host would be outside of the same 5-tuple right? If that's the case, there are chances of application running in user mode to be hooked into and priority can be lowered by a malware resulting in a DoS. I fear there might be some complications there, at least in terms of implementation, if we consider outside of the 5-tuple.

There are complications. But there are ways to associate the 5-tuples with each other by demonstrating knowledge of something that is in the clear, like the port number, or sending a STUN packet (on that same 5-tuple), or in the flow's initial packet (e.g., QUIC long header in the initial QUIC exchange), or using the same TLS Grease value for all of the associated flows...  Lots of methods can be considered.
Fully agree there are complications and there might be ways to soften some of them. We don't need to dig into those now, but leave that as a discussion item to have in the WG. Thanks

pulls.title: add use cases and include traffic nature
pulls.author: sridharangirish91

comments.body:
```suggestion
  1. In loss-prone networks or during reactive policy events, retransmissions cause long delays. All packets being treated the same can have challenges in efficiently handling/forwarding data. Today, there is no way to identify packets which are less important and/or loss-tolerant to prioritize packets in challenging networks and/or during reactive events.
```

```suggestion
  3. User's foreground application should receive priority over background tasks. For example, a user is typing in a document while playing a media in the background within the same session.
```

```suggestion
  REQ-SIGNAL-EXPOSURE-FAIRNESS: Means to expose the signal independent of the application should be considered. An example of such exposure is OS APIs.
```

If the client/user signals metadata A to be highest priority and then signals metadata B to be highest priority, do we just remove A (assign it default priority) and make B higher priority or discard the whole priority table and reset all the traffic to default values?
I purposely didn't include any signaling or host involvement in the process so as not to get into implementation details.

line 428 / requirement is not clear how it would work. Assuming that the e2e flow is encrypted, what would the user/client be able to signal about 'type of traffic within a flow' (i.e., to the network every packet looks the same). For example, in QUIC, only the connection id and spin bit are not encrypted and neither has meaning for packet priority. It would seem that only the server can indicate if a packet (or frame) has higher priority.

The E2E flow is encrypted (DTLS) but the signaling of metadata would lie outside of the DTLS payload... There should be a mechanism through which the network should be able to decipher the metadata (getting into the mechanism will be moving into implementation stuff and hence, I didn't get into it here). The metadata will obfuscated/encrypted by the server and the key will be sent to the client over the encrypted channel. The client would then share the key with the network/OS (in band or out of band). This is another use of client-to-network signaling that we had in the document but removed since it goes into implementation details. So left it as a requirement. Implementation would be ideally part of a different draft. Metadata can be filled into the CID for QUIC(https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-wing-cidfi/) or UDP options or anything else...

User/Client would provide a way to decipher the metadata alone and signal "Hey, treat the packets with metadata b10110 with highest priority".

There would be a <metadata,priority> pair for every flow and not all the metadata should be allowed to have highest priority is what being conveyed here, although how to design that is again getting into implementation part and so I strayed away from it too.
Thanks, I follow now, and agree with the proposal

```suggestion
  REQ-SIGNAL-VALIDATION: The network/OS needs to ensure that the user/client signaling of priority (if any) does not associate the same priority level with all traffic types within the same flow, thereby avoiding prioritizing of all the streams/traffic the same way.
```

```suggestion
Many of these flows do not originate from a content provider's network -- rather, they originate from a peer (e.g., VoIP, interactive video, peer-to-peer gaming, Remote Desktop, and CDN). Thus, the flows originate from an IP address that is not known before connection establishment, so there needs to be a way for the client to authorize the network elements to receive and hopefully to honor the metadata of those packets from a remote peer.
```

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: @boucadair - I think this pr requires your approval to merge since your review is still pending. Please can you approve if everything looks good?

```suggestion
It is recommended to encrypt or obfuscate the metadata information so it is only available to hosts and to authorized network elements. The method of encryption or obfuscation is not described in this document but rather in other documents describing how this metadata is encoded and exchanged amongst hosts and network elements. The privacy implications of revealing metadata to network elements need to be thoroughly analyzed. This analysis should ensure that any exposure of metadata does not compromise user privacy or allow unauthorized entities to infer sensitive information about the data being transmitted while maintaining minimal resource consumption.
```
Thanks Med!

```suggestion
However, prioritizing between flows, even for the same user/subscriber, presents the following challenges:
```

```suggestion
  2. Identifying whether the traffic belongs to a single user or multiple users from a single network attachment (e.g., tethering or LAN connected to a CPE). The network will enforce per-subscriber policies, not per-host.
```

```suggestion
  3. Enforcing fairness to all the flows belonging to a single host. For example, it is a challenge to prevent a platform from marking certain flows as low priority at platform layer, bypassing the application, to (de)prioritize certain applications over all the other applications on the same host. Such unfairness can be revealed during certification or public benchmark efforts, though.
```

```suggestion
Taking into account these challenges, and despite the use case is described in the document, inter-flow (de)prioritization requirements are out of the scope of this document. 

> Future versions of the document may re-consider this conclusion as a function of the comments received from the TSVWG.
```

Signaling and retrieval of the signals may not be performed at a single layer (although not encouraged). This APIs is required even if one single channel is used so that any application can consume the signals.

pulls.title: updates for issue#66
pulls.author: John-Kaippallimalil
pulls.body: Revised draft to address points identified in this issue.

comments.body:
Erm, I don't agree this would be a good example.  This would require more than one round trip for server to notice the changed congestion level after the client complains about loss or excessive ECN-marked packets received, requiring the client to then signal the server (via HTTP, updated SDP, or similar).   Why not have the server send packets marked differently the whole time?  Doing so would allow the network to drop less-important packets or forward important packets without suffering the greater-than-one-round-trip (*) delay.

(*) greater than one round trip because a reasonable client will not react to a single packet loss or single ECN-marked packet, but rather to several.


I suggest simply deleting this paragraph starting with "For example, when the application determines"

I agree that the example is not too good, but wanted to convey what the intention with "application server can decide on the priority" was.  The aim with using some dynamic process to determine priority marking was that different flows with the same content, to different users would be marked differently.
And I agree that the idea is not well developed and  it may be better to just delete it.
Updated the revision to remove the text as suggested.

reviews.author: John-Kaippallimalil
reviews.body: The changes look good to me.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: Incorporated via #70.

```suggestion
{{Figure-netshaper}} shows a bottleneck (access) router on the path of packets from Server to Client.
```

```suggestion
A network shaper in the router manages QoS of flows of multiple users and can buffer (delay), discard, or apply other flow control rules. Application layer signaling and feedback between Client – Server (A – in the figure) adjust transmission rate over a period of several RTTs using feedback and congestion control algorithms.
```

```suggestion
Network shapers observe flows and apply policies to maximize performance but are not aware whether  there is a high preference for one flow (UDP 4-tuple) over another flow belonging to the same user and network attachment (e.g., a subscriber connection, a 3GPP PDU Session. See {{net-attach}} for more details).
```

```suggestion
Clients may provide an (access) router with preferences of which flow (UDP 4-tuple) has relative priority among flows of that network attachment using H2N (C - in Figure).
```

```suggestion
Clients may also provide information to an (access) router to drop, when resources are congested,  'lower priority'-marked packets of a flow (UDP 4-tuple) temporarily which can in turn allocate bandwidth to other flows of that same network attachment.
```

```suggestion
Streaming media packets carry audio or video between servers and clients.
```

```suggestion
REQ-PACKET-PRIORITY: Packet priority relative to other packets within the same transport flow (UDP 4-tuple).
```

```suggestion
REQ-PACKET-DELAY: Metadata to indicate whether a packet can tolerate delay.
```

```suggestion
For example, an on-going file copy operation flow (UDP 4-tuple) of a remote desktop user can tolerate more delay than the flow carrying graphics updates.
```
Are we delving into inter-flow priorities, outside of the same UDP 4-tuple? I thought we mindfully wanted to move away due to a lot of complexities.

IMHO, Even if the requirements are overlapping, Streaming and Interactive Media should be separate items, given they are 2 big use cases that comprise of most of the internet traffic. On the other hand, we can merge interactive media, accommodate delay and mixed traffic into one.
User Preference might not belong here given that is agnostic of the traffic type but is an end user option. I am not sure if combining these 2 makes sense
Again, we should refrain from any inter-flow discussions IMO.

pulls.title: reworking the doc to make it more focused. Moving some parts to exten…
pulls.author: sridharangirish91
pulls.body: …ded section in the appendix

comments.body:
```suggestion
Collaborative signaling from client-to-network and server-to-network can improve the user experience by informing the network about the nature and relative importance of packets (frames, streams, etc.) without having to disclose the content of the packets. Moreover, the collaborative signaling may be enabled so that clients and servers are aware of the network's treatment of incoming packets. Also, client-to-network collaboration can be put in place without revealing the identity of the remote servers. This collaboration allows for differentiated services at the network (e.g., packet discard preference), the sender (e.g., adaptive transmission), or through cooperation of server/client and the network.
```

```suggestion
This document lists some use cases that illustrate the need for a mechanism to share metadata and outlines requirements for both client-to-network and server-to-network. The document focuses on flows bound to the same user.
```

```suggestion
Wireless networks including 5G and WLAN inherently experience large variations in link quality over sub-RTT intervals and on the other hand applications such as interactive media demand both low latency and high bandwidth. Maximizing network utilization and end user experience under such conditions is challenging. Factors that affect wireless networks include change in channel conditions, interference between proximate cells, and end user mobility. These variations in link quality can be in the order of a millisecond or less {{5G-Lumos}} while congestion control takes several tens of milliseconds (more than one round-trip time (RTT)) to estimate data rate. Similarly, application servers that encode and serve live or interactive media take time to adjust the encoding level and other processes to match the network rate. End-to-end congestion control algorithms are far from being optimal when the link quality is highly variable in sub-RTT timeframes and the application demands both low latency and high bandwidth (e.g., {{Section 2.1 of ?RFC6077}}). In these conditions, applications settle for a lower throughput when latency is prioritized, or for higher throughput at the expense of much higher delays.
```

```suggestion
While rate control based on feedback for a flow (UDP 4-tuple) is evidently not able adapt for sub-RTT changes in available wireless channel resources, an application server can provide information on a per-packet basis that a network shaper may use to allocate the available resources more effectively. {{5G-Octopus}} has shown for volumetric video packets and a rate controller that errs on the side of overestimation, that the network shaper can drop low priority frames of a group of pictures (corresponding to transient wireless link bandwidth drops) and still achieve significantly better performance than state-of-the-art based on feedback. With not fully encrypted packets, networks may use heuristics to build an "implicit signal" gleaned from a packet to prioritize or otherwise shape flows. However, implicit signals are not desirable as they lead to ossification of protocols as result of introducing unintended dependencies {{?RFC9419}}. When packet contents are encrypted, the approach of using implicit signals is no longer viable.
```

```suggestion
The requirements for this server-to-network (S2N) metadata are described in {{server-network}}. The client may provide information to an (access) router to drop lower priority marked packets of a flow (UDP 4-tuple) temporarily which can in turn redirect bandwidth to other flows of that network attachment, especially during a reactive event.
```

comments.body: The main body of the draft now refers to 3 requirements (REQ-MEDIA-AV-SEPARATE; REQ-PAYLOAD-CLIENT-DECIDES, REQ-MEDIA-KEYFRAME) that are in the Appendix. This blurs the line on what sections in the Appendix are normative and informative. As a partial remedy, I have made 2 updates  (see my commits above) to indicate that these requirements are "enhanced".

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body:
> The main body of the draft now refers to 3 requirements (REQ-MEDIA-AV-SEPARATE; REQ-PAYLOAD-CLIENT-DECIDES, REQ-MEDIA-KEYFRAME) that are in the Appendix. This blurs the line on what sections in the Appendix are normative and informative. As a partial remedy, I have made 2 updates (see my commits above) to indicate that these requirements are "enhanced".

Hi John, thanks for the text. I agree with REQ-MEDIA-AV-SEPARATE and REQ-MEDIA-KEYFRAME but I doubt if REQ-PAYLOAD-CLIENT-DECIDES causes any issue with traffic analysis. I have moved the statements you have made into the requirements definition itself to keep the main body short and succinct while keeping the remedy in place as well.

comments.author: John-Kaippallimalil
comments.body:
Hi Sridhar, Re: traffic analysis comment may apply for QUIC - where a the sender may schedule packets in any order (RR, priority, deadline, or even mix multiple media types in different FRAMES of the same packet). Plus there is the option to add chaff packets or stuff packets to not be able to detect based on size/frequency. This enhanced metadata should obviously not be used where effort is being taken to mask it from middleboxes in the network. On the other hand RTP is different (except if it is RoQ).

Having this kind of dependency between Appendix and main body is not ideal in my view. The gist of the impact/effect on other parts of the main body should be described there, as otherwise its hard for a reader to figure out what the impact would be to realize that requirement. Its fine if the preference is to to keep more of the details in the Appendix.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
> Hi Sridhar, Re: traffic analysis comment may apply for QUIC - where a the sender may schedule packets in any order (RR, priority, deadline, or even mix multiple media types in different FRAMES of the same packet). Plus there is the option to add chaff packets or stuff packets to not be able to detect based on size/frequency. This enhanced metadata should obviously not be used where effort is being taken to mask it from middleboxes in the network. On the other hand RTP is different (except if it is RoQ).

Seems best to discuss once in Security Considerations (or Privacy Considerations) section, which we already discuss at https://github.com/SpencerDawkins/net-collab-rqmts/blob/main/draft-kwbdgrr-tsvwg-net-collab-rqmts.md#privacy-considerations-privacy

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body:
> The main body of the draft now refers to 3 requirements (REQ-MEDIA-AV-SEPARATE; REQ-PAYLOAD-CLIENT-DECIDES, REQ-MEDIA-KEYFRAME) that are in the Appendix. This blurs the line on what sections in the Appendix are normative and informative. As a partial remedy, I have made 2 updates (see my commits above) to indicate that these requirements are "enhanced".

If that's the case, then we can mention media streaming in extended use case as well, where we go little deeper into the use case and explain the extended requirements there while keeping the basic ones in the main section of the draft.

We can combine 1 and 3 in media streaming as just a way to prioritize different traffic differently and least priority ones can tolerate loss. We can then move 2 and add a use case where we can get into audio video separately as well as key frame there.
Alternatively, we could move CLIENT-PAYLOAD-DECIDES to the main doc and keep 2 there. Given AV and KeyFrame requirements are not required for Client-payload-decides and doesn't have any traffic analysis complications, it could be a valuable client-to-network signal in the main doc too.

pulls.title: Moving requirements out of use cases. Rewording metadata text to be more coherent.
pulls.author: sridharangirish91
pulls.body: Requirements in metadata doesn't make sense since signaling the metadata satisfies the requirement.

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body: I have some troubles with some changes. Some smell solution-related.

comments.body: Not sure what is meant here.
Idem as above
Idem as above

```suggestion
REQ-PRIVACY-ADDITIONAL and REQ-SIGNALING-AVOIDANCE are satisfied by
```
Not sure we need to have this statement.
Why are we adding this? We are not designing solutions.

```suggestion
: During detected reactive events, the network implements a
```

```suggestion
: The ISP deploys access routers closer to users to reduce link
```
This is deployment-specific. We can't mandate what an ISP can do.

also, 'the prioritized flow' smells like prioritizing *between* flows.  

There should be no harm in a flow that is marking some (or all) of its packets as important, even if it is doing so maliciously.
Similar concern about "by this" in many of the updates (since we have definitions already for each requirement)

Deploying network routers closer to the user/client does not resolve "continuity" requirement. What matters is that when the session is re-established (after handover), any negotiation of metadata is handling during the session re-establishment.

By this, I meant the REQ-CLIENT-DECIDES is met by signaling Client flow authorization. The prev text shows Requirements under metadata definitions, which really didn't make sense given signaling these metadata is the way those requirements would be met. Maybe we can word it better to say 

"REQ-CLIENT-DECIDES is met by signaling Client Flow Authorization as part of client-to-network signal"?

Same line of thought for all other items as well.

```
The general trend in wireless networks is to deploy the wireless
router closer to the user. This can help with low link latency but
can result in more frequent handovers as the user moves between
routers.
```

This was already there in the text. I just moved it under the requirement itself since it seems to be referring to a way it is done today (or at least reads so to me). Do we remove the whole statement altogether then?

Now reading it again, the whole Abuse and Constraints section seems to be in a "between flows" context than within the same flow. I agree with Dan as well, no harm in marking all packets important within the same flow. Can we remove the whole section?

I'll reword it and move the scalability to extended operational considerations and make ISP scale a requirement. That way the language is more consistent. Telling the metadata information should be kept to a minimum and then saying that is a requirement as well doesn't make sense
same line of thought as REQ-CLIENT-DECIDES. Updated the language to be more specific.
same line of thought as REQ-CLIENT-DECIDES. Updated the language to be more specific.

because we are not prioritizing between flows, I believe we are immune from abuse.  Let's say a flow was all VoIP without any silence detection or anything, for example, so it is a solid stream of bits at a fixed rate.  Every packet could be marked High Priority.  Or Low Priority.  It doesn't matter.  If, while that VoIP is going on, the user adds a file transfer or the user adds screen sharing, then the priority begins to matter -- assuming the client considers the VoIP most important, the VoIP should get the highest priority among the 3 streams on that same flow (file transfer, VoIP, screen share).  A malicious sender would be noticed by the client both in the poorer user experience and in the packets being received which have incorrect priority markings.

it doesn't matter where or how things are deployed; what matters is the radio interface can provide feedback to the thing-doing-rate-limiting.  Which might be itself, but it still has to provide that feedback internally. It might be a different physical device or a VM or, in 5G, a virtualized function.  Doesn't matter at our level of requirements.
I agree Dan. Added text to reflect this into security considerations and removed Abuse section.
Agreed! Removed those lines altogether and stated the requirement for what it is, succinctly.

reviews.author: danwing
reviews.body: changes look good, but I would hold off to hear from Med on his previous comments to be sure those are closed (or need words changed).

reviews.author: John-Kaippallimalil
reviews.body: Updates address my comments. Thanks!

comments.body:
@Sridhar: The trend to deploy wireless routers closer to the user is driven in 3GPP by capacity and latency concerns. That this results in more frequent handovers was to motivate the problem/requirement for continuity after handover. (i.e., unlike 4G-like centralized deployments, the lack of continuity for metadata would result in many users/sessions being affected). 
Just wanted to clarify: I don't see this as a big issue and what's in the draft is fine.

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body:
Thanks for clarifying. 

Some few changes, fwiw. Thanks.

comments.body:
```suggestion
maintain for each additional flow it handles should be kept
```
no need to know this is "media flow". Removing is consistent with the assumption in the draft that we don't care about the application type, etc.

```suggestion
There may be a large number of flows handled by the server
```

```suggestion
server identity, and securing the metadata.
```

```suggestion
(not specifying inter-flow priority), the document does not induce concerns related to a specific
user or client declaring all flows or a subset of them as being more important. Such abuse concerns are thus not applicable.
```

```suggestion
```
Agree, just "flow" is better. (same for similar changes below)

pulls.title: simple change to Introduction, without making it shorter
pulls.author: danwing

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Wanted to create a PR against Dan's one but mistakenly committed there. 

FWIW, it is easy to use the diff to track the changes: https://author-tools.ietf.org/api/iddiff?url_1=https://SpencerDawkins.github.io/net-collab-rqmts/draft-kwbdgrr-tsvwg-net-collab-rqmts.txt&url_2=https://SpencerDawkins.github.io/net-collab-rqmts/introduction_tweak/draft-kwbdgrr-tsvwg-net-collab-rqmts.txt

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
> Wanted to create a PR against Dan's one but mistakenly committed there.
> 
> FWIW, it is easy to use the diff to track the changes: https://author-tools.ietf.org/api/iddiff?url_1=https://SpencerDawkins.github.io/net-collab-rqmts/draft-kwbdgrr-tsvwg-net-collab-rqmts.txt&url_2=https://SpencerDawkins.github.io/net-collab-rqmts/introduction_tweak/draft-kwbdgrr-tsvwg-net-collab-rqmts.txt

Thanks for the link, that eased comparison.

I see new:

> 	7.3.  Abuse and Constraints	
> 		
> 	   It is important that not every flow be prioritized; 

Flows can be prioritized against each other?  I mean, I agree we want that in the future.  But the new text brings a new idea:  have the ISP router be where the client's various non-cooperating applications "fight it out" for which flow is prioritized.  That is a different model than what I had envisioned previously (my previous mental model is some software library on the client would "fight it out").  Doing this at the ISP router might well be a good solution, *and* it allows a subversive ISP (read: all of them) to favor one flow over another (Facebook versus Dan-Tube, my new streaming video service).

We can consider merging this PR in future versions. Thanks.

Thanks Med. I'd most likely have to resolve bunch of conflicts when we decide to take it in. So I've kept the branch alive. Will resolve those after 121 and reopen the pr :)

```suggestion
in {{sys-considerations}}. Privacy ({{privacy}}) requires that metadata should not provide
```

```suggestion
Research (e.g., {{5G-Octopus}}) indicates that media applications can achieve better Quality of Experience (QoE)
```

IETF likes acronym expanded on first use. We don't use QoE later, but it's useful to have **QoE** in the document if someone searches for it.

```suggestion
flows belonging to the same user and network attachment (e.g., a subscriber connection, a 3GPP PDU
```

```suggestion
‘lower priority’-marked packets of a flow (UDP 4-tuple) during Reactive Management,
```

```suggestion
allowing bandwidth allocation to other packets of the same UDP 4-tuple.
```

comments.body: these lines were all moved to Section 5.3, "Metadata Negotiation Support", approximately line 514, as the server-to-network per-packet metadata is not related to API, but rather something that is learned (negotiated) by the client talking to its network.

pulls.title: consolidate 'traffic analysis' to just the Privacy section; 'frequency analysis'->'traffic analysis' (the more common IETF term)

```
411
```

comments.author: John-Kaippallimalil
comments.body: Good to remove unused terminology. Changes look good.

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body: We don't need to restrict the direction at the stage. It is not easy for a reader to digest why per-* is possible for a given direction only.

comments.body:
```suggestion
of a connection and thus can be exchanged once or as needed. This is communicated per flow (i.e., UDP 4-tuple) between client and network.
```

```suggestion
the nature and characteristics of the traffic each packet carries. This needs to be communicated on a per packet basis.
```

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body: Thanks, Dan.

comments.author: John-Kaippallimalil
comments.body: Changes look good.

```suggestion
Media flows are vulnerable to traffic analysis even without per-packet
```

```suggestion
metadata (see, e.g., {{traffic-analysis}}). The security aspects of the
```

```suggestion
media payload / transport are not in the scope of this document; these
```

```suggestion
are mentioned here only to provide context for metadata privacy.
```

```suggestion
Protocols such as TLS, SRTP, and QUIC offer some mitigations (like padding)
```

```suggestion
but are vulnerable to traffic analysis ({{traffic-analysis-2}}).
```

```suggestion
obfuscation is out of scope.
```

Modifying metadata in transit seems a security concern, not a privacy concern. Should this be moved to security considerations?  Also, CIDFI (as one per-packet metadata mechanism we could consider) prevents such modifications, so this blanket statement needs more nuance.

```suggestion
({{Section 7.4 of ?RFC6973}}).

To best preserve privacy, implementations might also consider less granular per-packet marking, for example marking all audio and video packets the same and only marking a background data transfer with different metadata.
```

reviews.author: danwing
reviews.body: one addition and one move of paragraph to Security and I'm good.
